Posts.Content: bopeep wrote: There is reseach going on at the University of Michigan that is focusing on cancer stem cells, which are believed to fuel the spread of breast cancer. Stem cells are being targeted with experimental drugs at UM in what has been described as"groundbreaking clinical trials that researchers hope will lead to a breakthrough in treatment for cancer with stem cells." "By using experimental drugs to block these cancer stem cells, doctors hope the tumors will shrink or at least stop spreading and will lead to better ways to treat -- and possibly cure -- the disease that is the nation's second-leading cause of death.  "The research will be highlighted next week in Detroit during the World Stem Cell Summit, a gathering of 1,200 prominent stem cell scientists, industry leaders and advocates from 30 countries.  "But the trial means much more to Mary Diesing, who for eight years has battled breast cancer that has spread to her bones, spine and liver. "This is my last hope," said Diesing, 69, who's been traveling 500 miles from her home in Indian River, Mich., in recent weeks to participate in the trial. "My doctor told me either I do this or go into hospice." The World Stem Cell Summit was first held in Texas five years ago as a response to outcry over research using embryonic stem cells -- derived from leftover embryos from a couple's fertility treatment. But the summit has evolved to include work on cord blood cells, regenerative medicine and adult stem cells, from which cancer stem cells originate. Among the speakers will be U-M Comprehensive Cancer Director Max Wicha, who launched the trials to block breast cancer stem cells that Diesing is enrolled in, and has since begun collaborating with other pioneering scientists to make Michigan a leader in the field. "We rarely use the 'C word' -- cure -- but the intent of research today is not to study (cancer) but to treat and ultimately to beat it," said Jeffrey Trent, president and director of the Grand Rapids-based Van Andel Institute, which is planning to partner in the future with Wicha. "There is so much hope that we're positioned today with the information from the (human) genome, with the biologic expertise and understanding of the stem cells, I think we can be at the vanguard of treatments that hopefully will lead toward not just longer, disease-free survival but quite literally cures. That's the hope of the cancer stem cell approach."   This is really exciting news indicating there might be a breakthrough in curing this disease during the lifetime of many women here.   For more information , read the entire article..   www.detnews.com/article/201009...  Dx 8/9/2010, IDC, Stage IV, mets, ER-/PR-, HER2- Log in to post a reply

Posts.Content: Oct 7, 2010 08:58AM bopeep wrote: I'm glad to hear the news that 3 weeks of rads might be as good as six weeks because that's where I quit.  And I'm glad I quit because my last scan showed damage to my right lung from the radiation.  I don't know how extensive or permanent it is but I've had a very bad cough ever since started radiation, but that could be due to an infection and/or possible new mets as well.  Of course, my radiation was to my right axillary area under my arm, not my breast where you women are getting yours. I was part of the Tailorx study back in 2007 for my chemo.  Now I'm in another study that looks at circulating cancer cells to preview whether a chemo is going to be working or not.
Posts.Title: October 2010 rads mamaof3bugs JFV

Posts.Content: Sep 21, 2010 05:32AM - edited Aug 20, 2013 02:47AM by bopeep Well, I'm here too.  I actually started about a ten days ago but it seems like forever.  I was originally dx'd in 2006 and now I have a recurrence under my arm.  This is my second time around with rads. The femara seems to be working well.  I feel that the radiation is doing its job and I am glad to be getting it.  But I am getting so bored with it.  I calculated that I have whole nother month to go!! That seems like double forever. It will be nice when I can sleep late again and not worry about getting to my 9:30 appt evey day. Bo
Posts.Title: October 2010 rads mamaof3bugs JFV

Posts.Content: Oct 2, 2010 07:55AM bopeep wrote: Fatique on Rads:  I just spent the last week recovering from 3 weeks of rads, and I had no idea how much it had affected me.  I've been sleeping 12 and 15 hours a day, and it's been doing wonders!  You will get tired, but you will recover!
Posts.Title: October 2010 rads mamaof3bugs JFV

Posts.Content: Nov 20, 2010 04:27PM - edited Aug 20, 2013 03:14AM by bopeep Jenin, Judy... Thanx for saying what I've been feeling about this woman.  I am really beginning to have my doubts.  She is the kind of person who seems to have very little time, she forms her opinions without my input and is annoyed when I tell her things that that contradict her ideas.  No, she has no idea what I went through.   Yes, I did go through a living hell and  I began to wish that I could just die right away and get it all over with.  I never want to go through that again.   This is the same oncologist who insisted I had no infection when I had pertussis, who refused to give me antiobiotics though I begged for them before chemo  Then, a few weeks later she decided she changed her mind and gave me antibiotics.  The antibiotics helped, but things started to get worse, I knew I had a inflammation because I know how my immune system overreacts, she disagreed and refused to give me steriods because I might still have an infection.  She told me that I had lung cancer and the best thing for me was chemo.  She was wrong on everything.  The chemo did nothing but exacerbate the inflammation and the radiation damage and spread the inflammation to a much larger area of my lungs; this is what the pulmonologists told me. These months that I have been under her treatment are a time when my health and quality of life have been close to zero.  It has been a horrible ordeal and it was not necessary.  Why should I trust her now?  And what will I have to deal within in the future?  She also made very little effort to get me a procedure that I really need, that can save my life.  I don't know whose side she's on, but it doesn't seem to be mine.  If there's one lesson I've learned in life it is to be commander of your own ship.  No one else knows or cares about YOU better than Yourself and if you are going to survive at anything you have to be pushy.  You cannot depend on others to fight your battles as well as you can. Bo
Posts.Title: Good news?!! I'm hope so...!! bopeep bopeep

Posts.Content: Oct 27, 2010 05:00PM - edited Aug 20, 2013 03:02AM by bopeep  This sounds really serious.  I'd ask for some numbers anyway.  Numbers don't scare people over here, they've seen numbers that would make your toes jiggle and turn gray! Avoid googling negative subjects. Turn off the computer, get comfortable, turn off the lights. Think instead about positive things...people in your life, happy things that happened recently, who you can snuggle with right now.  Open the windows and let the fresh air in and the wind and enjoy the evening.  Think about the trees blowing outside (if you have them), the stars, and how special it is to be you, even if it just for tonite. Bo

It sounds like I am a bit more sensitive than most, so we'll see For starters I've asked my husband to pick up Senekot, Lactulose, Colace and camomile tea. Oxy-incontally, Bo

Posts.Content: bopeep wrote: We talk about sex and other kinds of personal issues, but here's a subject NO ONE wants to talk about and it's become a major deal, probably no. 2 in my life.  I know a lot of us are on narcotics and chemos that really are wrenching our insides but we don't want to talk about.  My nurses aren't much help, it's just Try This! or Try That!  No dosage suggestions.  The label says not to use if for over 7 days or if you have rectal bleeding.  No rectal bleeding?!! Ha Those were the days.... We don't need a lecture on how to eat properly lots of fruit and fiber, we've known all about this for years and years and I eat lots of fresh fruit and fiber. Those narcs dont only slow things down; they bring them to a dead stop; they remove normal sensation from your bowels so you get little warning about what's going on until it's already happening [they also remove the ends of words and whole words out of sentencs when you are typing]. Is this happening to you?  I guess it DEPENDS..on what you're taking. I've been taking Metamucil for years and it's been my friend, except when you're taking narcotics.  If you've tried something that is working and not blowing your guts out every morning post here...if you've gotten regular enough that you dont have to RUN to the bathroom every morning please let me know. Oxy-inconitently yours, Bo  Dx 8/9/2010, IDC, Stage IV, mets, ER-/PR-, HER2- Log in to post a reply
Posts.Title: Bowel Blues bopeep bopeep

Posts.Content: Oct 20, 2010 05:34AM - edited Aug 20, 2013 02:58AM by bopeep CM and KSkier, I've been trying Miralax. It certainly goes down easy for me it is not at all gentle.  I'm am wearing depends at night becuase I have to run so fast in the am.  And there it is 3 of 4 swift trips in succession.  In the after noon I get cramping, and some f-a-r-t-s that are so painful they feel like bricks with points.  One dose miralax has produce 4 days of gas & emergency bathroom trips so far. Sunflower, that prune juice treat sounds very nice.
Posts.Title: Bowel Blues bopeep bopeep

Posts.Content: Oct 30, 2010 06:33AM - edited Aug 20, 2013 03:03AM by bopeep  Well, I have found a very gentle old fashioned laxative that works and is kind to your gut:  plain old mineral oil.  Take 1-3 tablespoons before bed and next morning things happen with no cramping, very easy to deal with.  Mineral oil is tasteless and is as easy to get down as vegetable oil.
Posts.Title: Bowel Blues bopeep bopeep

Posts.Content: Nov 20, 2010 03:58PM - edited Aug 20, 2013 03:14AM by bopeep Hey Guys, This procedure is not the Embolism thing which sounds a lot hairier to me.  It is much more simple and straightforward, just flush the liver with high concentration chemo, and flush it out the other end of the liver before it reaches the body.  BTW, my operation is not the procedure that is up for currently up for approval by the FDA, the procedure which will be  approved by FDA is a much better procedure because it is not invasive and repeatable--the same thing is done except with tubes and needles.  This procedure will be available to everybody this spring.   I am opting for the surgical route now because my cancer is so aggressive, has not responded to *any* treatment, and I am so limited on time. It is a one shot deal and cannot be repeated. I've had lots of PMs and requests for the surgeon's name, and I've been told I am the *first* breast cancer patient he is considering and that it is possible that I might be approved on that basis.  When I have my appointment on December 1 we'll all find out.  Please PM me if you are still interested in the surgical procedure and cannot wait until spring. Bo
Posts.Title: Good news?!! I'm hope so...!! bopeep bopeep

Posts.Content: bopeep wrote: Hey Gals, Haven't had a working computer or much to report in the way of news for a few weeks except that I am S L O W L Y getting over my chemo disaster of two weeks ago.  I am still very short of breath, my fingers are numb, but my lungs are working well.  I can go for walks every day but I sound like an old lady huffing and puffing around the house.  I've been having fun rearranging rooms upstairs and getting them ready for a special guest this Christmas and happily planning on being alive for the holidays. I am taking a chemo holiday this month to give my lungs and body some time to recover from the massive lung inflammation I am being treated for and recover from my last traumatic chemo blast.  My oncologist is not happy.  She actually wants me to take something like cisplatin-navelbine next time after other doctors have told me to never to do this if I want to stay alive. She was hostile and disdainful last visit because I went to the ER after chemo, kept me waiting and hour and a half--causing me to miss a later appointment. Scornful because I am in a wheelchair (I was very shaky and tired and my knees felt like jello that day)...you'd better get out of that wheelchair if you want to get accepted into a trial she says.  I had found an ongoing study that I thought would be perfect for me, one that is doing liver perfusions that expose the liver to high levels of chemo without hurting the rest of the study.  She called at my request and had one of her nurses called me this Monday to let me know they were not taking new patients....too bad, so sad...but that was that. No dice. I decided to make another call myself.  To make a long story short I was connected to a message machine but within 5 minutes a very friendly, sympathetic man who I'll call Jay called me back.   He turned out to be the administrative head of the organization that has been running this liver research project for last few years.   After a short discussion of the seriousness of my situation---my oncologist has told me two months to live without effective treatment--he told me he had a doctor at the University of Pittsburgh who was a close personal friend of his who would perform the procedure for me. He told me to call him immediately, if I didn't hear back within 24 hours to let him know, and predicated on that by telling me to feel free to call him anytime about anything at all. This doctor is the only person in the country performing these procedures, which he does as a surgery.  I called and left a message, but Jay obviously had made some calls too, because early the next day I got a number from the doctor's office from people who were seemed well informed about my situation and got me all set up.  My first appointment is set up for Dec. 1 and if all goes well, I will have this surgery before Christmas.  The procedure is generally 100% successful at eliminating cancer from the liver, the expected outcome is no progression...so I'll have my dream come true of being NED before Christmas!! Of course there may still a few hurdles to jump before I get there...but I'm putting on my ruby slippers and I'm ready to take off (and also thinking about changing oncologists). XOXOXO BO  Dx 8/9/2010, IDC, Stage IV, mets, ER-/PR-, HER2- Log in to post a reply

Posts.Content: Oct 28, 2010 08:45AM - edited Aug 20, 2013 03:02AM by bopeep I am praying for you!  Don't let those heartless doctors leave alone and worrying...I cannot believe in this day and age how they could actually do that!!! This is a time to trust in God.  A few months ago, when I first got my dx, I made a pilgrimage to St. Joseph's Oratory in Quebec, which sits on a very high hill.  There are steps for worshipers to climb kneeling.  I prayed for a cure on each step and my knees got very sore.  I got no clear answers, but when I was more than half way up I did some to hear a voice from somewhere... The Lord is my shepherd;​ I shall not want.  I will fear no evil: for thou art with me.. Remember it is only the shadow that frightens you this shadow will pass through our lives many times but the lord always protects us.  These words have never failed me since---Bo

Posts.Content: Oct 25, 2010 10:52AM bopeep wrote:  Huunh accupuncture, maybe I should try this.  Metamucil was my friend for years but it doesn't mix well with oxycotin.  I tried dulcolax with 1/2 senna, that was a bit too harsh.  So now I'm trying dulcolax on its own.  An impacted bowel was one of the more  horrible experiences you can go through life.   I can also imagine it would be better to get through life without a hemmorhoidectomy!!   or a bowel tear!!   Right now farts are as painful as the real thing.   I once had a intestinal obstruction at the point where the small bowel attaches to the large bowel.  It had been painful throughout the day, but that night it got very bad, I was writhing with pain on the bathroom floor, trying to figure out how to detach myself from my body.  My husband came in and found me and told me I was utterly gray, and he asked "Are you ready to go the hospital now."  When I stood up I feel a rush of liquid in the middle of my abdomen like Niagara falls; something was very, very wrong.  I fully expected to be going in for emergency surgery, when on the way there, I realized the pain was gone!  I guess the blockage had cleared itself.
Posts.Title: Bowel Blues bopeep bopeep

Posts.Content: Oct 30, 2010 08:49AM - edited Aug 20, 2013 03:03AM by bopeep Well, even before I ever got ill this last time, I found out that one of the very best things you can do to get things moving is go for a run.  There were lots of times when I would go running and there was no way to avoid this:   at some point during the run everything in my gut would shift downward and there was no stopping things. I had two sets of woods along my route (right in my neighborhood) where I could escape, get behind a tree, and whammo!!!  A total cleanout every time.   I was always afraid someone would see me or figure out what I was doing. But the image of  a real accident was much worse.

Posts.Content: Oct 12, 2010 02:58PM bopeep wrote: I am really surprised that they would leave you on Tamo so long if you were getting progression.  I think Femara is the best of all of the AIs.  Sorry about your progression I hope you see some major re-gression. The most dramatic story I've heard about femara was a woman whose liver was nearly completely destroyed by cancer.  She was told to get her affairs in order and given some femara just to buy her a little time.  Three months later her tumors had all shrunk to half, and 6 months later they had entirely disappeared. Good luck.

Posts.Content: Sep 23, 2010 04:38AM - edited Aug 20, 2013 02:47AM by bopeep Quiche:  I love your quote!!    CT:  Sounds like you had an utterly miserable time with TC (taxotere+cytoxan).  Were you getting Neulasta or nuepogen shots?  They are supposed to make a big difference.  When I took TC in 2007 I had a terrible time with infections--UTIs, respiratory infections.  My insurance didn't quality me for Neulasta and the Neopogin shots which were supposed to be 5 days sequential after infusion never happened as they should because the clinic was not open on weekends.  I was sick and frightened a lot.  Thank God you are done with it, for good I hope. I am considering taking taxotere again, but this time my insurance will pay for neulasta.  It's supposed to be one of the most toxic chemos out there, but one of the most effective and produces the most longevity.  But at what cost?   I will have to consider that as well too.  Welcome here and I promise, the worst is over! Welcome Roberta: I missed your post while I was typing mine.  This is a new group, but a nice friendly one.  I already have a very positive feeling here. Bo

Posts.Content: Sep 30, 2010 08:38AM - edited Aug 20, 2013 02:50AM by bopeep Quiche, Glad you're taking femara, I think it's the best of the 3 AIs with the least side effects.  When I started it 4 years ago my SEs were minimal, just the hot flashes and a little aching in my ankles at night.  After a few years I started having some serious bone loss and pain, so be proactive about getting your bone supplements and Vitamin D.   I finally went off femara and I think that is what triggered my recurrence; looking back if I had taken just a two-week break I would have been fine, because later on when I restarted it again I had no SEs at all. A good massage can solve the lymphedema problem...I never went to a specialist.  One night when I was on the telephone my husband grabbed my arm and started a massage, he seemed to put his heart and soul into  it.  When he was done my arm felt fine and I never had another symptom.  BTW, I'm outta here for a while and back to chemo, but I'll be checkin on ya!! XXXXOOO Bo

Posts.Content: Sep 27, 2010 06:21PM - edited Aug 20, 2013 02:49AM by bopeep These are all great posts...thank you. I'll sleep better tonight.  Sunny, you're just doing great with your mets.  I am hoping this is nothing but the remains a cold and that I'll need to  exercise and breathe deeply to get all the gunk out. Chainsaw, sorry to hear about your lung mets but glad to see they've reduced. I have been on AIs for 4 years.  I was off for a few months and back on in July.  But when I switched to Aromasin in August everything went hayware and I started getting a lot of progression.  I switched right back to Femara but the progression just continued.  Somehow a switch got thrown. Sometimes ER+ go negative twith distant mets or ER+s get resistant to AIs, that is why I am anxious to start chemo, and like you, said, I want it give it GOOD KICK IN THE BUTT. Bonnie and Meima, thank you again for your sweet prayers and support.  Every prayer means a lot to me. XXXXOOOO

Posts.Content: Sep 28, 2010 05:09PM - edited Aug 20, 2013 02:50AM by bopeep Well, I just got back from my appointment with my new oncoloigst...what a difference.  They actually were not too concerned about all the coughing, because apparently EVERYBODY is coughing, even regular people.  So maybe it's not lung mets yet. I am starting Taxol in Monday, and they will keep me there until I'm NED.  I like that optimism.  I'll lose my hair but to be honest, I didn't like what my hairstylist did with it anyway.  I'm ready for a new head of hair. I can already hear the birds chirping next spring.  Thank you ALL.  People make al the difference.
Posts.Title: Any luck with lung mets regression? Anybody? Help! bopeep bopeep

Posts.Content: Oct 13, 2010 11:33AM - edited Aug 20, 2013 02:55AM by bopeep Just bumping this thread up again hoping you guys with lung mets experience can see... I just got the news that the problems I've been having with coughing, breathlessness, and chest pain were more likely related to lung cancer than anything else...the last few weeks have been miserable.  Some days I just coughed nonstop.  I had no energy for anything.  I actually had to use a wheelchair at the hospital to go to my appointment yesterday. The encouraging news is that chemo appears to be working very well in the liver anyway (just one treatmnet), so it will probably work on lung mets as well.   For those of you that recovered from lung mets...did you get rid of it completely, or does it come back in a different place?   Bo
Posts.Title: Any luck with lung mets regression? Anybody? Help! bopeep bopeep

Posts.Content: bopeep wrote: I still have not had any chemo.  On August 4 I had a petscan that showed numerous small mets to my liver and "innumerable small ground glass" nodes in my lungs to be checked in 3 months. However, my cancer is more aggressive than most, at least that was the oncology test and Notthingham ratings suggested. I am now fearing the worst.  I got a light sore throat at the beginning of September and I've had a cough that has been getting worse and worse. Saturday I had such a terrible coughing fit that lasted for 6 or 7 minutes I couldn't breathe so I decided to go to the ER.  They gave me a breathing treatment, an inhaler, and prednisone.  I thought I was seeing signs of improvement when I stayed home today and got some rest and I was feeling more optimistic. But I start to cough as soon as my husband got home because I was talking. And then we took our usual walk...going up the hill the cough began again frantically.  I cough whenever I need to breath deeply into my lungs.  I just hope its not too late.  I see my new oncologist tomorrow.  Asking you again for your support and prayers...thank you.. Dx 8/9/2010, IDC, Stage IV, mets, ER-/PR-, HER2- Log in to post a reply

Foobs, I absolutely hate PINK!  Good point about the brochures.  I thought the what color is bra thing that went around Facebook was little tasteless too.

Posts.Content: Sep 12, 2010 03:24AM - edited Sep 12, 2010 03:26AM by bopeep Darlene, Ead, Apple, Robin, Dreamwriter, thank you all for your words and kind thoughts!!  I feel like I now have a Team!!  Darlene, your success with liver cancer gives me hope!...Please tell me all about it if you have time, maybe you can cut and paste some old posts and PM them to me.  The thing that worries me most now that I apparently had been responding to Femara all this time and suddenly, OOPs! the AIs don't work anymore?  This is why I am having the liver biopsy. It may be a stupid thing to hope for but I am hoping I have some other sort of liver disease.   At least it would be a logical explanation for the lab reports...although this sudden change at the time of surgery is still a mystery.  My liver didn't look healthy to me...it was "fatty."  5 pm Cocktail Hour has been an institution in my family since I was teenager.  We stopped last week.  That and tylenol.  And I am thinking about getting rid of anti-depressants too because they break down in the liver. I live in an area where there are some major universities with famous medical research departments, but let me tell you...I have had bad, very bad experiences there that I have not already mentioned here.   One of my oncologists was a cancer researcher with a Harvard degree....the one who took me off femara.   What is an NCI accredited institution? Bopeep

Posts.Content: Oct 30, 2010 05:49PM - edited Aug 20, 2013 06:03AM by bopeep Of course, Jeanne, this is very, very scary; you need to get on something right away.  Why did you stop Ixempra?   Are you sure you really can't start again or find a way to deal with what the problem was. I hate those nurses.  WTH, here we are CANCER patients, we are DYING, and it's more important not to disturb our oncologist's golf game than do deal with our problems??!!  It infuriates me.   Sometimes I think oncologists are a special category of doctor that are specially programmed to be hardened and insensitive to what their patients go through. Be pushy, don't be polite.  Your life is more important than being nice to people right now.  Keep calling.  Annoy the H* out of that nurse. Bo
Posts.Title: So Scared - No Place To Hide jeanne46 claygirl

Posts.Content: bopeep wrote: Hey Folks, I am very much in need of a special treatment for my liver mets...like one of the targeted chemos or embolistic treatments for the liver, and I am willing to travel.  I've read about lots of interesting treatments for treatment of cancer that has spread to the liver that expose the liver to high levels of chemo without harming the rest of the body, but unfortunately I don't know of any that are accepting patients now.   Please...if any of you know where I might find a reputable hospital--preferably a NCI cancer research facility that is doing something like this..please let me know.  I live in Michigan but I can travel. My problem is that I have had a serious lung inflammation for about two months now from whooping cough that has weakened my stamina and makes it very difficult for me to deal with chemo.  I was first treated with Taxol which I tolerated well, but unfortunately the Taxol was not controlling the cancer.  I had an infusion of Navelbine and Carboblatin last Tuesday that knocked me totally off my feet.  I was in the hospital for two days for extreme breathlessness and fatigue, I am now home, but still very very weak and recovering very slowly. Physically, I don't think my body is going to be able to handle any more traditional whole body chemos for at least month or possibly longer.  I have extensive cancer in my liver that needs to be stopped before it starts to spread. A targeted chemo to the liver could do a lot for me right now. Please let me know if any of you know where I might find treatment. Thank you very much!!!!! Bo  Dx 8/9/2010, IDC, Stage IV, mets, ER-/PR-, HER2- Log in to post a reply

Posts.Content: Oct 29, 2010 05:24PM bopeep wrote: ooh yah, my doctors would even look me in the eye.  I wanted to know whey they weren't going to clean up a sloppy surgery with unclean margins..."oh we wouldn't want to put you through the recovery process."  (I'd recovered from that as though it were a small cut).  Lots of wimply excuses that weren't saying "we want to help you," instead the words between the lines were "we don't want to bother with you, you're going to die anyway so why not get on with it!" Shameful, shameful doctors, because with this kind of atttitude they actually ruined my chances at beating the problem, it's almost as though they caused the problem.  Certainly the messy surgery spread cancer all over my body leaving a clear path.  I really don't know what they teach doctors these days or how they come up with these ways of dealing with things.  There's nothing ethical here.  Nothing at all. Bo
Posts.Title: stage IV "discrimination"? jenny66 lindaa

Posts.Content: bopeep wrote: Hey all,   Back from the liver biopsy and am still in Recovery...I am required to stay for 4 hours even though I already feel recovered.  A liver biopsy is not the for the faint of heart.  I was awake all through it and felt every jab and at one point almost fainted, but the team of people taking care of me were just wonderful.  Don't know what pathology will find, but I am sure they have plenty to work with!   Do not eat gingerbread and whipped cream as your last meal of the day when you have to fast before a procedure!   Eat a nice sensible meal of protein and vegetables!  I'll never do that again..     Bo  Dx 8/9/2010, IDC, Stage IV, mets, ER-/PR-, HER2- Log in to post a reply
Posts.Title: Done with Liver Biopsy! bopeep bopeep

Posts.Content: bopeep wrote: I've been putting up a brave front for my husband and my family.  I've been telling them I am not afraid of death, that I can deal with this.  But I am still reeling dizzily from the news I got on my birthday last month that I am Stage IV.  I never never thought this would happen. I was 4 years out after a lumpectomy and clean nodes, ER+, PR-, Her-.  Oncotype score 36.  My oncologist took me OFF Femara last March because she thought I was over the danger period and she wanted to give my bones a break.  She had very little clinical experience. Three months later I had a lump under my arm, then two lumps.  They were removed with unclean margins and another tumor left behind.  My new oncologist showed me pictures of my liver with some small spots and told me "I am 80% sure there are cancer, but I don't want to do a biopsy because I'd probably get a false positive."  Meanwhile like an idiot I am hoping those spots are anything BUT cancer and I am very concerned about this sloppy surgery under my arm with a suspicious lump I can still feel.  My surgeon is on vacation.  So I talk to a couple of other surgeons who see STAGE IV written all over my charts and they simply shake their heads and decide to do nothing.  I call my oncologist for help and he is unconcerned, he whispers in my ear "I think you have cancer all over your body!" There is no evidence for this.  I am told to get back on AIs and they will take care of everything.  Well they didn't. Since my surgery my tumor markers are up to 60 from 28, and my liver enzymes have doubled and jumped out of normal range.  Something is very very wrong with this picture. I have not discussed this with my oncologist because my appointment keeps on getting rescheduled for more important things, like getting going with radiation, and the liver biopsy my radiologist just ordered for me.  We are not sure what kind of results we will get from this because the spots are so small.  I have no mets anywhere else in my body, no bone mets, except for an almost microscopic shadow on a lung. I feel that I cannot trust my oncologist, or even my surgeon, who did such a sloppy surgery.   I feel like they have all written me off...why bother, she's Stage IV.  I want to be anything BUT stage IV.  I want to fight this as aggressively as possible and at least get a few years, and now I am wondering if I am even going to get a few months.   I have been so terrified of what is happening to me and not going to happen that at times I have felt suicidal.  Just get it all over with right now and then I don't have to deal with this.  But this would not be fair to my family, who I love dearly. Right now things don't look very good.  Dx 8/9/2010, IDC, Stage IV, mets, ER-/PR-, HER2- Log in to post a reply

Posts.Content: Sep 12, 2010 12:20AM - edited Sep 12, 2010 12:56AM by bopeep Robin, thank you for your post. My social worker (who comes free with to all patients at the cancer center I go to) has been suggesting that I need to try another oncologist.  There are some good people here; I don't really want to change institutions because there are some positives:  my radiologist is wonderful, the women are wonderful and its very close by.  The problem with my surgeon is that he is very highly thought of around here, and I think he was just over-worked and tired when he did my surgery and everyone is trying to protect his reputation. When I see another oncologist (I am going choose the head honcho here who has a lot of experience and published research on breast cancer), I am going to ask him to fine me another surgeon.  If I get a negative liver biopsy, I am going to ask for a radical mastectomy that removes *everything* in that area including *every* axillary node.  No reconstruction. My worst fear is that the rise in the tumor markers is from the sloppy surgery and things ARE actively spreading to my breast and arm pit... I can already feel a new lump. Thanks for being concerned.  I've feel like just a loner, everyone is treating me like I am nothing but a nuisance.
Posts.Title: Sorry to be joining you and I'm scared to death... bopeep leprechaun

Posts.Content: Sep 15, 2010 12:58AM bopeep wrote: Thank you Apple, Crissy & Cat.  I'm definitely ready for one of the UPs on the roller coaster ride. Today I tried to make another appointment with a more experienced oncologist on the staff where I go and was told that second opinions are rarely done in-house.  Bummer!  Seems like to me it would be a good idea to get doctors on the same staff to confer and talk to one another where they all have access to the same records. I do not want to the university, but I guess I have no choice.  The last time I got a second opinion there was after the aforementioned surgery.  I was told my original surgeon was held in such high regard that they wouldn't treat me. The consulting surgeon said he was going to call my doctor personally to make sure I was seen right away; well he did make the call, but my surgeon offered only to see only after a few months had passed.  I keep going in circles. Maybe I need a new city.

Posts.Title: Liver Biopsy Results Positive for BC Mets bopeep meima-Bev

Posts.Content: Sep 23, 2010 10:42PM bopeep wrote: Thank you everybody for your encouragement and wisdom. I had a terrible visit with my oncologist after I got the news today.  He was smiling ear to ear and offering me options like tamoxifen.  I told him I wanted Big Guns liked taxotere and he told me that wouldn't work because I already had taxotere; it was my first chemo--you know the prophalactic one.  I do not trust him at all.  I will never see him again and he offered to do nothing for me. I've done taxotere; it was pretty strong and I had a lot of problems with infections, but I'm wiser now and I'd do it in a heartbeat if I thought it would be effective.  I am very puzzled because my latest biopsy from the recurrence under my arm in July was 90% ER+.  I think the liver cancer is something different...maybe it's just liver cancer.  It's not responding to the AIs but the tumors under my arm did. I have an appointment next week with another oncologist at a different hospital.  She's got great credentials and I think she can help.  In the meantime I'm scared to death.  I read my original petscan report (I had to get copies of everything for the referral) and it described the cancer in my liver as "innumerable small spots on both lobes."  That was when my tumor markers were only at 38.  Now they are 97.   I am afraid the cancer is spreading everywhere. Sorry for being so negative.  It seems like I've just had one bad break after another with my treatment:  sloppy surgery, oncological incompetence (taking me off the AIs for example), lots and lots of mistakes and delays that are too numerous too mention. I can't believe how unlucky I've been and how badly I've been treated, but I'm not the only one whose gotten bad treatment on these boards, so I guess I shouldn't complain too much.  I just wish something GOOD would happen for a change. Thanks for all your posts.  Hopefully I'll have something nice to post before too long.

Posts.Content: bopeep wrote: I need your help....the AIs are not working.  My tumor markers have been steadily rising and my liver enzymes are 4-8 times what they should be.  I am scared.  It is definitely time for chemo.  But which one? I have a number of small (1 cm) tumors in both lobes of my liver. I'd like to shoot with the Big Guns--taxotere, but only if it will buy me more than a few months.  The last time I took taxotere the side effects were devastating; the worst being chemo brain and inability to do things I could do in the past.   Those of you who had liver mets and recovered from them, please tell me what chemos you used, the side effects, and how effective they were.  I'm interesting in find out about the non-hormonal chemos (including her-). Thanx so much.  I have an appointment with an oncologist today who I don't trust a lot, and an appointment on Tuesday with a new oncologist.  I'd kind of like to wait for her opinion, but the other hand, I don't like the delay. Bo  Dx 8/9/2010, IDC, Stage IV, mets, ER-/PR-, HER2- Log in to post a reply
Posts.Title: Liver Biopsy Results Positive for BC Mets bopeep meima-Bev

Posts.Content: Sep 24, 2010 11:26AM bopeep wrote: I guess tumors are in a constant state of evolution.  When I switched to Aromasin to Femara, everything stopped working, and then Femara, which had worked before, wasn't working either.  I think the liver is such highly metabolic organ that it can change things.  There are still some new chemos out there to try, like Xeloda (sounds very easy to take) and Navelbine (sounds very very toxic). I read an article somewhere here on the BC site that you can actually treat hormone positive cancers that no longer respond to the AIs with small amounts of estradiol.  The estradiol causes some of the cancer cells to die, and the ones that remain are re-sensitized to the AIs. In any case, there is a study going on that I hope to participate in, where you try different chemos and your blood is monitored for cancer cells which are examined to gauge whether or not the treatment will be effective.  That way, they can get you OFF something that isn't effective before there is too much more progression and try something else.   Sometimes things go around in circles...drugs that were ineffective once become effective again.  As cancer evolves, treatments evolve to keep up with them.  That's the general idea anyway.

Posts.Content: bopeep wrote: Hello Chemo Buddies,   I may be up for some rounds of adriamycin soon since I have advanced metatastic cancer, and this drug is supposed to be especially effective at this stage.  I avoided it in the past because of concern about heart problems.  But my heart and EF are very good.  I have read that there is a lot of nausea, fatigue, fogginess.  How long does this last after each infusion?  I may be getting mine WITHOUT cytoxan.   Four years ago I took TC as my adjuvant regimen and I found it tolerable.  The day of infusion was just like any other day, and the next day.  Fatigue starting hitting day 3 and day 4 I was in a total fog.  But by day 5 I started to recover.  Around noon I'd have a Diet Pepsi and a Darvocet and be good as new.  Usually got in a few runs before the next infusion on Day 15.   I will say I did have some long range effects..fatigue and the need to sleep 10-12 hours per night for 2-3 years afterwards.  Some mental loss as well, but I recovered that too.    Let me know how you're doing on Adriamycin.   Thanx,   BO  Dx 8/9/2010, IDC, Stage IV, mets, ER-/PR-, HER2- Log in to post a reply

Posts.Content: Dec 2, 2010 08:03PM - edited Aug 20, 2013 06:18AM by bopeep
Posts.Title: Which is worse for SEs--Taxotere or Adriamycin? bopeep msmpatty

Posts.Content: Oct 3, 2010 03:41PM - edited Aug 20, 2013 05:52AM by bopeep Jenny, Before I decided which AI to take I did a lot of research, that was back in 07.  It seemed to me that the best one was femara; it was the most effective and there seemed to be more SEs with Arimidex.  At first it was easy to take but unfortunately, after a few years the SEs started building and I had a lot of bone loss and bone pain.  My oncologist took me off femara for a few months.  Unfortunately, that led to Stage IV mets before our next appointment. I think if I had just taken a break for one or two weeks I could have gotten right back on Femara with no problem.  The most serious SEs were gone within that time.  I've also read about other women taking a break for just a week, and coming back to femara with side effects greatly reduced.  I eventually started taking Femara again 4 months later--when I found a lump under my arm.  I had no SEs at all when I restarted. Another oncologist decided to switch me to Aromasin with no break after Femara.  At that point my tumor markers started spiraling and haven't stopped  My liver enzymes doubled and quadrupled.  I stopped responding entirely to all the AIs and my cancer is now acting like its triple negative.  So I am really spooked about that experience with Aromasin.  I say, stick with what works.  Just take some breaks.  Think about getting injections for your bones. Bo

Posts.Content: Sep 30, 2010 02:17AM - edited Aug 20, 2013 07:20PM by bopeep To everyone here who posted for me:  I want to thank all of you for what you did for me here.  The advice you gave me was what I needed to hear.  I have acted on it and it has made ALL THE DIFFERENCE. RobinWendy and DarleneDenise, You were the first two that chimed in and you gave me detailed, strong and good advice.  I read every word and thought everything over carefully.  I have now FIRED my oncologist.  Yesterday I met with my new oncologist who has excellent credentials at an NCI university.  She and her nurse oncologist spent nearly three hours with me going over my history and making a plan. They are on top of the latest research, very knowledgeable, and feel positive about the outcome.  They are setting me up to start Taxol on Monday with more scans and tests this week.  They plant to meet with me on Monday, so If the scans and tests show changes that might poin towards a different therapy they will be ready to go with it.  Things happen very quickly around here! If the Taxol doesn't work, they will switch to other chemos until they find one that does.  My bloodwork will be monitored frequently.  I am also going to be part of a study that looks at circulating cancer cells after the first cycle of treatment, to assay whether or not the treatment is working, so that a switch can be made early on. Chainsaw, Becky, Gingerbrew, Ead, Apple, Chrissy, Nopey, Lowrider, Bernicky, Bonnie, Lowrider, Lane, Marybetz, Meg, Lori, Cat, Chrissy...you all added to the chorus and gave me the confidence to go through with the right decision.   Mandy, Vilma,  and Lori thanks for your prayers and good wishes. Scuttlers and Bambaloos, it was so very kind and caring of you to offer your own cancer treatment center in Houston as a possible place for me.  This meant a lot. Allison, you were SOOOO right.  My thoughts exactly  So, I am going to get the treatment I need and the plan is to get me NED or stable within the next 3/4 months.  I am not worried about losing my hair.  I've heard Taxol is a lot gentler than Taxotere which I had 4 years ago so I am not concerned, I've also heard that the taxanes after often the best first line treatment for Stage IV recurrence.  Feeling very positive. I am so grateful that you all were here.  It made a big difference for me.  Hope I didn't leave anyone out.  You ALL much such a difference. BO XXXXXXXXXXXXOOOOOOOOOOOOOOOOOXXXXXXXXXXXOOOOOOOOOOOOO
Posts.Title: Sorry to be joining you and I'm scared to death... bopeep leprechaun

Posts.Content: Oct 17, 2010 05:02PM bopeep wrote: Sometimes we have to trust our own judgement.  You live with your wife from one day to the next and you probably have better instincts about how she is doing than a doctor who reads reports and sends you ambiguous messages. Something is missing from the picture.  Follow your instincts and pursue things until you get satisfactory explanations.  Maybe you need another opinion.

Posts.Content: Sep 12, 2010 05:01AM - edited Sep 12, 2010 05:27AM by bopeep I checked the University hospital (one of the hospitals where I've been treated) and it was NCI accredited.  But I think these researchers are so full of themselves and wrapped up their ivory towers that ordinary patients bore them.  My oncologist there (the second one) certainly seemed foggy on thel details of my case....at one point she said, "The cancer was awfully small, wasn't it, under 1 cm?"...well it was not one cancer but three cancers, one visible on mammo, one not..total size over 2.5 cm plus another small area of DCIS.  I don't think she even knew what an oncotype score was.
Posts.Title: Sorry to be joining you and I'm scared to death... bopeep leprechaun

Posts.Content: Sep 13, 2010 01:12AM bopeep wrote:
Posts.Title: Sorry to be joining you and I'm scared to death... bopeep leprechaun

Posts.Content: bopeep wrote: I've been putting up a brave front for my husband and my family.  I've been telling them I am not afraid of death, that I can deal with this.  But I am still reeling dizzily from the news I got on my birthday last month that I am Stage IV.  I never never thought this would happen. I was 4 years out after a lumpectomy and clean nodes, ER+, PR-, Her-.  Oncotype score 36.  My oncologist took me OFF Femara last March because she thought I was over the danger period and she wanted to give my bones a break.  She had very little clinical experience. Three months later I had a lump under my arm, then two lumps.  They were removed with unclean margins and another tumor left behind.  My new oncologist showed me pictures of my liver with some small spots and told me "I am 80% sure there are cancer, but I don't want to do a biopsy because I'd probably get a false positive."  Meanwhile like an idiot I am hoping those spots are anything BUT cancer and I am very concerned about this sloppy surgery under my arm with a suspicious lump I can still feel.  My surgeon is on vacation.  So I talk to a couple of other surgeons who see STAGE IV written all over my charts and they simply shake their heads and decide to do nothing.  I call my oncologist for help and he is unconcerned, he whispers in my ear "I think you have cancer all over your body!" There is no evidence for this.  I am told to get back on AIs and they will take care of everything.  Well they didn't. Since my surgery my tumor markers are up to 60 from 28, and my liver enzymes have doubled and jumped out of normal range.  Something is very very wrong with this picture. I have not discussed this with my oncologist because my appointment keeps on getting rescheduled for more important things, like getting going with radiation, and the liver biopsy my radiologist just ordered for me.  We are not sure what kind of results we will get from this because the spots are so small.  I have no mets anywhere else in my body, no bone mets, except for an almost microscopic shadow on a lung. I feel that I cannot trust my oncologist, or even my surgeon, who did such a sloppy surgery.   I feel like they have all written me off...why bother, she's Stage IV.  I want to be anything BUT stage IV.  I want to fight this as aggressively as possible and at least get a few years, and now I am wondering if I am even going to get a few months.   I have been so terrified of what is happening to me and not going to happen that at times I have felt suicidal.  Just get it all over with right now and then I don't have to deal with this.  But this would not be fair to my family, who I love dearly. Right now things don't look very good.  Dx 8/9/2010, IDC, Stage IV, mets, ER-/PR-, HER2- Log in to post a reply
Posts.Title: Sorry to be joining you and I'm scared to death... bopeep leprechaun

Posts.Content: Oct 18, 2010 07:36AM bopeep wrote:  I don't fit your criteria at all, I am 62, but to think you are going through what you are at your age is a whole new ball game that is hard for me to imagine.  Strength and courage to you.  I am praying that your youthful vigor will help you live to the point where there is a cure for this madness.   And I think that's very good possibility.  Sending you prayers, angels, and red roses.

Posts.Content: Sep 18, 2010 01:57PM - edited Sep 18, 2010 01:59PM by bopeep Feeling a lot better this morning after a good sleep.  They must have given a HUGE dose of percocet yesterday because I was really flying most of the afternoon.  This morning no pain.  Meima, thanks for your prayers...a good report would be fabulous. Mon..you are right about checking the biology of the liver, this is exactly what I wanted to do because I am wondering if the liver problems are even related to the breast cancer.  They might be entirely something different.  And Jenny, if the liver turns HER+ that would be very good news as well. Flachica, you all had seemed to have had a good recovery from liver mets; I hope my experience is as good.  Makes me feel positive.  Geez...it's great to have anything to feel positive about about after a Stage IV dx! Bo
